Exploring efficient and highly selective ammonia synthesis electrocatalysts can advance the development of both modern agriculture and industry. Graphene nanobuds (GN) feature both fullerene and graphene characteristics which inspires new design ideas of electrocatalysts for N2 reduction reaction (NRR) to ammonia based on the novel GN with traditional Fe-, Co-, Ni-N2 sites. Among these structures, CoN2-GN is investigated as the most promising candidate with a limiting potential of -0.83 V through a distal pathway. The excellent activity and selectivity for the eNRR can be attributed to synergistic effects originated from both confinement space of buds (fullerene fragment) and curvature of the junctions. Especially, acting as an H-activator to N2, the ‘neck’ C atoms in the GNs improve the selectivity significantly for eNRR and facilitate the subsequent processes. This research would greatly contribute to develop the novel, efficient, multi-component graphene-based eNRR catalysts. Graphical abstract First principles calculations show that Co-N2 sites incorporating on the graphene nanobuds (CoN2-GN) could act as a promising eNRR catalyst on account of synergistic effects from confinement and curvature of the junctions, where the ‘neck’ C atoms can act as H-activators to N2. Image, graphical abstract Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ammonia (NH3), a necessary part of the nitrogen cycle, is essential not only for supplying various nitrogen-containing chemicals like fertilizers, but also as an emerging energy carrier [1–3]. The traditional Haber–Bosch process is the main method for industrial ammonia synthesis, however the high-temperature (300−500 °C) and high-pressure (200−300 atm) conditions result in tremendous energy consumption [4,5]. Currently, electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction reaction (eNRR) is recognized as an efficient process because of using renewable energy (generated by solar or wind power) at ambient conditions [6–8]. Unfortunately, eNRR has also its significant shortcomings, namely the low selectivity for reduction of the dinitrogen to ammonia versus protons to H2 [9,10]. Despite of various exploration strategies on the functionally active catalysis sites in recent years [11], the effects of nanostructured supports have relatively rarely investigated. Driven by the intensive understanding on the nanomaterial compositions with miniaturization roadmap over the recent decades [12], numerous nanostructured carbon materials in different dimensions have been designed to synthesize [13]. As a superstar material, graphene has attracted a lot of attention thanks to its advantage of superior electronic and mechanical properties [14,15]. Therefore, it is a feasible strategy to integrate graphene with other different components and units for electrocatalysis, energy storage, and other applications [16,17]. So far, some typical synthetic methods towards the construction of 3D CNT/graphene nanostructures have been reported in experimental [18,19]. Especially, Meng et al. successfully pulled individual CNT bundles from graphene in situ for the first time, and they suggest that the junction between the CNTs and graphene layers is likely chemically bonded [20]. Such multiscale systems by constructing the nanostructured carbon materials in different dimensions, and the graphene nanobuds (GN), namely combination of fullerene with graphene therefore deserve intensive attention. Till now, various evidence elucidate that enhanced properties, including non-linear optical response and ORR activity [21,22], are inspired on nanobuds referring to the pristine graphene [23]. Therefore, we envision that such combination of fullerene and graphene for graphene nanobuds could make a significant improvement on the eNRR performance theoretically. Notably, transition-metal-N x derivatives are increasingly popular alternatives and thus are applied in catalytic reactions owing to their high electrical conductivity and noble-metal-like behavior [24,25]. Especially, a series of Fe, Co, Ni-N sited- catalysts have been investigated as efficient ORR [26], CO2RR [27–29]and NRR catalysts [30–32]. Furthermore, a new concept of ‘confinement-induced catalysis’ has been proposed by Prof. Bao and his coworkers [33], and in the atomic and molecular scales, the confined space has been verified to lead to complicated changes in molecular configuration, atomic arrangement, and electronic structure, etc. [34–36] Recently, Meng et al. successfully synthesized the oxidized CoP particles encapsulated in carbon nanotubes (OCoP/CNT), which exhibits a high NH3 yield of 39.58 µg h − 1 mg-1 cat and high Faradaic efficiency (FE) of 19.4%; [37] Lv et al. reported a confined electrocatalysis strategy by constructing a carbon nanotube inserted porous metal–organic framework (CNT@MOFs), and then verified its remarkable performance toward eNRR with a high activity and FE [38]. It has been revealed that confined nonprecious metal-based materials within carbon nanotubes could act as active sites for electrocatalytic ammonia synthesis. Besides promoting the catalytic activity of the catalyst, the introduction of Fe, Co, NiN2 sites is also aimed to boost the kinetics for reactants to enter into the cage, and the remarkable significance of the synergy of curvature and confinement effects necessitate to be distinguished for unraveling the multiscale mechanism. Herein, we theoretically modelled the graphene nanobuds with Fe, Co, Ni-N2 sites as shown in Fig. 1 and noted them as FeN2-GN, CoN2-GN and NiN2-GN, respectively. A typical FeN2-GN, consists of an imperfect C80 attached to graphene via a ‘neck region’, where it could act as a natural access. According to our calculations of density functional theory (DFT), the CoN2-GN material is the most potential eNRR catalyst with a theoretically limiting potential as large as −0.83 V among the three catalysts. The computed results indicate that the selectivity rather than the catalytic activity for eNRR plays a predominant role when Fe, Co, NiN2-GN compare to the Fe, Co, NiN2 sites anchoring on the flat graphene on account of the curvature of the junctions. 2 Computational methods All the calculations of spin-polarized density function theory were conducted by using the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [39,40]. Perdew Burke Ernzerhof (PBE) was applied to describe exchange correlation potential [41,42] and projector augmented wave (PAW) scheme was employed to consider the electron-ion interactions [43]. The plane-wave basis with an energy cut-off of 500 eV was adopted, and Brillouin zone integration was sampled by the Monkhorst-Pack k-mesh with 3 × 3 × 1 and 5 × 5 × 1 for structure optimization and density of states (DOS) calculations, respectively, and the convergence test results of k-points are listed in Table S1. The convergence criterion of force and ionic was set to 0.03 eV·Å −1 and 1 × 10−5 eV, respectively. Additionally, we used the DFT-D3 method with B-J damping to describe the van der Waals interaction [44]. An imperfect C80 was deposited on an 8 × 8 supercell of graphene to eliminate the interaction between one and the adjacent C80. The computational details of binding energy (E b), cohesive energy (E coh) adsorption energy (E ads) Gibbs free energy change (ΔG), the limiting potential (U L) and ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations can be found in the Supplementary Material. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Geometry and stabilities of Fe, Co, NiN2-GN To give an insight into the role of each cage-carbon that can be substituted by transition metal (TM) site, Bader charges populations on the GN are analyzed. As illustrated in Fig. 1, the Bader charge population on carbon in white color is about 0 |e|, which indicates that the adjacent carbon atom provides a relative non-polar environment, making the substitution of TMs much more feasible to take place. In addition, the substitution of other zero-charge sites located on the top-part and mid-part of the cage has also been clarified as shown in Fig. S1. These results verify the rationality of the substitution site that we selected and further ensure the possibility to access a stable structure. After the substitution, the Bader charge populations on Fe, Co and Ni atoms of Fe, Co, NiN2-GNs are 0.86, 0.77 and 0.74 |e|, respectively. It means that FeN2-GN has the most positive Bader charges on the active site of TM among the three catalysts. Besides, the spin-polarized DOS analysis was performed as plotted in Fig. S2, and it turns out that the metallic properties can be achieved in both pure GD and the Fe, Co, NiN2-GN models due to their DOS domination at Fermi level. We thus expected that the three TMN2-GN catalysts all exhibit electronic conductivity to achieve an efficient mass-transferring during the electroreduction of N2. For the assessment of thermodynamic stability, binding energy (E b), cohesive energy (E coh) and AIMD simulations are used for the wide descriptions. The difference between E b and E coh (∆E b-c) are calculated to determine if the catalyst could prevent both diffusion and aggregation. As a result, (Table S2) the value of ∆E b-c on Fe, Co, NiN2-GN are computed to 0.64 eV, 0.82 eV and 0.57 eV, respectively, where a more positive ∆E b-c means a better single-atom stability. Accordingly, the thermal stability is analyzed by performing the AIMD simulations as shown in Fig. 2 . The energies of FeN2-GN, CoN2-GN and NiN2-GN together with the TM-N and TM-C bond length were plotted, respectively. The energies of nanobuds systems and the corresponding bond length all keep in a small area throughout the AIMD simulations at 500 K for 20 ps, which confirms the remarkable stability of the catalysts [45]. 3.2 Adsorption of N2 on Fe, Co, NiN2-GN Generally, the adsorption and activation of N2 is of vital significance for the eNRR process as it is an important prerequisite for the subsequent reduction steps. We thus first studied the adsorption of N2 which is associated with the adsorption energy (E ads) of N2 adsorption. For the N2 adsorption, four possible adsorbed configurations are labelled as shown in Fig. 3 , including end-on adsorption of N2 in both (i) and (ii) types, and the side-on adsorption of N2 in both (iii) and (iv) patterns. After optimization, three configurations (i), (ii) and (iii) were obtained successfully on FeN2-GN and CoN2-GN, and all could be obtained on NiN2-GN. Compared with the 1.117 Å in isolated N2 molecule, the NN bonds in ads-type of (i) (ii) and (iii) are activated to be 1.131, 1.135 and 1.158 Å on the FeN2-GN, 1.130, 1.133 and 1.153 Å on the Co-N2-GN; and those are 1.130, 1.135, 1.147 and 1.159 Å in (i) (ii) (iii) and (iv) cases on the Ni-N2-GN, respectively. As a result, case (ii) shows the strongest adsorption of N2 with E ads of −1.19 and −0.85 eV on the FeN2-GN and CoN2-GN, respectively, while type (i) shows a stronger adsorption of N2 on the NiN2-GN. When it comes to the Gibbs free energies for N2 adsorption, as summarized in Fig. 3b, it is found that the ΔG ads values of all (iii) and (iv) are positive, we can thus rule out the possibility of the side-on cases. 3.3 Conversion of N2 to NH3 Generally, the six PCET steps of eNRR were described via the reaction of N2 + 6H+ + 6e− → 2NH3. Till now, two main types of mechanisms have been involved, including the dissociative and the associative pathways. The associative pathway is more accepted in the eNRR under ambient conditions, and it can be divided into four possible pathways, including alternating, distal, enzymatic and consecutive pathways in general [46–48]. The alternating and distal mechanisms start with an end-on N2*, whereas the enzymatic and consecutive mechanisms start with a side-on N2*. According to the data in part 3.2, the latter two mechanisms can be ruled out here, and hence we discuss the possible alternating and distal mechanisms in the latter sessions as depicted in Scheme 1 . The free energy diagrams and corresponding reaction intermediates are shown in Fig. 4 , Fig. 5 and Fig. S3. The key results of the three potential N2 systems are listed in Table S3. For Fe, Co, NiN2-GN, PDSs are the first hydrogenation step (*N2 + H+ + e− → *N2H), with the limiting potentials (U L = − ∆G PDS /e) of −1.15, −0.83 and −1.22 V, respectively. A comparison of the theoretically calculated ΔG max of different single-atom catalysts could be seen in Table S4. One can see that the CoN2-GN material is the most potential eNRR catalyst among the three catalysts, and it confirms the higher catalytic activity of the Co in the CoN2-GN with a moderate oxidation state among the three catalysts as discussed in the section of ‘Geometry and Stabilities of Fe, Co, NiN2-GN’. 3.4 eNRR & the competitive her It is well aknowledged that eNRR, from the perspective of experiment, usually proceeds at an applied potential which is very close to that of the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). Consequently, under aqueous solution, the competitive HER has been recognized as a vital challenge till now [50]. As for the selectivity of the eNRR catalysts, several calculation methods have been adopted in the previous studies: 1 In the most recent studies [31,49,50], the adsorption ability of *N2 (N2 + * → *N2) and *H (H + + e – + * → *H) on the real active site was compared (i.e. ΔG *N2 and ΔG *H), and once one N2 can be preferentially captured and associated to the active site rather than H atom, the competing HER will thus be suppressed accordingly. As shown in Fig. 6 , we calculated the adsorption energies of H atoms on the different carbon sites (C1-C10) together with the metal sites. It is observed that the E ads values for these H-chemisorption are −0.36, −1.32, −0.82, −0.45, 0.88, 0.30, 0.49, 0.53, 0.79 and 0.53 eV for the Co and C1-C10 sites, respectively, and he optimized structures of adatom-H on C1-C4 sites of CoN2-GN with their adsorption Gibbs free energies are shown in Fig. S5. It is worth noting that comparing with the most other ‘neck’ C sites, Co sites are much less energetically favorable to absorb the hydrogen atoms. 2 According to some studies [51], the eNRR selectivity could be identified by comparing the free energy difference between the adsorption of *N2H and *H (i.e. ΔG*N2H and ΔG*H), since most of the eNRR catalysts hold the hydrogenation step of *N2 → *N2H as the potential determining step (PDS). Here, *N2H is the preferred adsorbed species over *H for selective eNRR. The difference of Gibbs free energy change (δG = ΔG* N2H – ΔG *H) was calculated to hold a negative value of δG of −1.61 eV, and thus a better eNRR selectivity is distinguished from this point of view. 3.5 Curvature and confinement effects To obtain an in-depth understanding of the curvature and confinement effects on the Fe, Co, NiN2-GN, the comparative analysis of Fe, Co, NiN2 sites anchoring on the planar graphene (Fe, Co, NiN2-GO) towards eNRR was carried out. We depicted the optimized structures of Fe, Co, NiN2-GO catalysts in Fig. S4, and Fig. 7 shows a more obvious difference in the activity and selectivity of eNRR between the CoN2-GO and CoN2-GN. The maximum Gibbs free energies of the preferred eNRR pathways on Fe, Co, NiN2-GO are 0.82, 0.93, 0.94 eV, respectively. Referring to the difference of selectivity, the Fe, Co, NiN2-GN show their excellent performance. The above results should be precise, taking into account a fact that due to the electrostatic repulsion between the positively charged TM and the proton, the positive charge on the Co site can prevent the H + from approaching the TM site to form *H, and the ‘neck’ C atoms become the reasonable sites to support *H. Here, H* is calculated to bind the C1-C4 sites in the presence of adsorbed N2 molecule on active site and the Gibbs free energies of H-chemisorption are in the range of −0.66 through 0.02 eV (Figure S6). In this sense, proton can be reduced into the adsorbed H thermodynamic spontaneously, and the C sites can thus act as an H-activator for the eNRR. Moreover, the calculated electrostatic potential (ESP) for the CoN2-GN on the (001) plane was depicted in Fig. 8 , it can be revealed that the ‘neck’-carbon atoms between sp 2 and sp 3 have significantly lower electronegativity than those in planar ones and subsequently excellent nucleophilicity. Similarlly as our data, the curvature-dependent selectivity of electrocatalytic CO2 reduction on the nanotubes was claimed [52]. It is acknowledged that nanotubes with small radii tend to catalyze CO2 reduction to CH4 while on the nanotubes with larger diameters CO is the main product. Herein, it is plausible that CoN2-GN exhibits the better eNRR catalytic activity owing to its excellent confinement effect and appropriate space, and its superior selectivity exhibited here is resulted from the curvature effect. 3.6 Origin of the NRR activity on CoN2/GN To track the origin of the NRR activity of CoN2-GN, we further investigate its electronic properties in detail. As depicted in Fig. S6, the projected density of states (PDOS) of N2-adsorbed CoN2-GN show that the 3d orbital of Co can hybridize with 2p orbital of the *N2 in a moderate and appropriate way in contrast to the FeN2-GN and NiN2-GN which is accordant with the calculated ΔG ads of N2 on the three catalysts. As revealed frequently, spin moment plays an indispensable role to activate the inert N2 [53,54]. Referring to our computed results, CoN2-GN has a total spin moment of about 0.796 μB, which is mostly attributed to the Co atom (0.693 μB, 87%). After the adsorption of N2, some spin moments on the Co atoms transfer to the adsorbed N2 (Fig. S7), thus boosting the N2 activation and promoting the subsequent processes. In addition, to reveal the vital roles of Fe, Co, NiN2 sites, the calculations of the Fe, Co, Ni embedded in the GN (Fe, Co, Ni-GN) and Fe, Co, NiN3 anchoring on the GN (Fe, Co, NiN3-GN) were also carried out. The optimized structures of Fe, Co, Ni-GNs and Fe, Co, NiN3-GNs are shown in Fig. S8, and their NRR potentials are then evaluated by calculating the Gibbs free energies of the step of *N2 → *N2H (ΔG *N2 → N2H). Obviously, the ΔG *N2 → N2H for the Fe, Co, Ni-GN are 1.05, 1.04 and 1.12 eV respectively, and they are 1.10, 0.88 and 0.94 eV for Fe, Co, NiN3-GN, inferior to the above optimized Fe, Co, NiN2-GN. According to the results displayed all, the important role of Fe, Co, NiN2 sites in association with synergistic space confinement and curvature effects was evidently figured out. Conclusions In summary, we have designed and simulated the eNRR performance of three catalysts of FeN2-GN, CoN2-GN and NiN2-GN with comprehensive DFT computations. Our results demonstrate that CoN2-GN would be the most potential eNRR catalyst having a theoretical limiting potential as large as −0.83 V lower than that on the Ru(0001) stepped surface, which has been reported as the most active bulk metal toward NRR with the limiting potential of −0.98 V [55]. The calculated ΔG max value are comparable to the recent single-atom catalysts in publish (Table S4). Its most advantageous feature is that the ‘neck’ C atom of the GN could act as a reasonable site to support *H, thus improving the selectivity for the eNRR and also facilitating the subsequent process. The better eNRR catalytic activity of CoN2-GN can be assigned to its excellent confinement effect and appropriate space, and its superior selectivity has also been proved owing to the curvature of the junctions supportively. These mechanistic understanding could provide some ladders to experimental and theoretical researchers for exploring the novel, effective, multi-component graphene-based catalysts for the eNRR and other electrochemical reactions. coredata.dc:description: Exploring efficient and highly selective ammonia synthesis electrocatalysts can advance the development of both modern agriculture and industry. Graphene nanobuds (GN) feature both fullerene and graphene characteristics which inspires new design ideas of electrocatalysts for N2 reduction reaction (NRR) to ammonia based on the novel GN with traditional Fe-, Co-, Ni-N2 sites. Among these structures, CoN2-GN is investigated as the most promising candidate with a limiting potential of -0.83 V through a distal pathway. The excellent activity and selectivity for the eNRR can be attributed to synergistic effects originated from both confinement space of buds (fullerene fragment) and curvature of the junctions. Especially, acting as an H-activator to N2, the ‘neck’ C atoms in the GNs improve the selectivity significantly for eNRR and facilitate the subsequent processes. This research would greatly contribute to develop the novel, efficient, multi-component graphene-based eNRR catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Synergize curvature and confinement effects for Fe-, Co-, Ni- N2 sites on graphene nanobuds towards eNRR
